Images & Words https://blog.waitsforsleep.net/posts/2021-08-01/ -

Interesting post from a LessWrong user who’s resorted to using 5-minute games on chess.com to sort of “measure” his/her cognitive capacity/variance on a day-to-day basis. I’ve been toying around with the idea of picking up playing chess again on a hobby basis (without putting any time to study things like openings and what not). I should perhaps park some time in the morning to do this.

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/nvRauqCD3u5hdkLm9/chess-and-cheap-ways-to-check-day-to-day-variance-in#comments

Vice report on unique and technically sophisticated hacks that are being deployed en-masse by Gojek riders in Indonesia to get around the one-algorithm-fits-all mentality that’s being enforced by modern gig platforms like Gojek/Grab/Uber etc.

https://www.vice.com/en/article/7kvpng/delivery-drivers-are-using-grey-market-apps-to-make-their-jobs-suck-less

I always thought the pattern of the ultra rich buying sports teams was just an example of people indulging their childhood fantasies as soon as they had access to practically infinite wealth.

Boy was I wrong. The explanation was always “follow-the-money”.

https://www.propublica.org/article/the-billionaire-playbook-how-sports-owners-use-their-teams-to-avoid-millions-in-taxes

Analysis of how financialization and deviating from engineering roots has nearly destroyed the competitive edge of an engineering behemoth. I’ve read similar stories about Boeing and its current predicament before.

https://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2021/07/how-intel-financialized-and-lost-leadership-in-semiconductor-fabrication.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+nakedcapitalism+%28naked+capitalism%29

Analysis of the QAnon conspiracy/community phenomenon from a game designer’s perspective. Its incredible how many of these mechanics are mirrored in what I think the author is rightfully identifying as a game,who’s objective is propaganda, playing the population.

https://medium.com/curiouserinstitute/a-game-designers-analysis-of-qanon-580972548be5

The best Covid 19 vaccine yet ?. Did not know that the apparent delay between different vaccines coming out does not have anything to do with the underlying technology. Instead it is a reflection of the manufacturer’s ability to organize a large clinical trial.

So I guess the limiting factor is project management rather than engineering.

https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2021/06/novavax-now-best-covid-19-vaccine/619276/?utm_source=feed

Sunday, June 27, 3:35 PM

Useful advice on how to better plan vacations to maximize joy derived from it.

https://www.theatlantic.com/family/archive/2021/06/vacation-happiness-plan/619275/?utm_source=feed

Sunday, June 27, 3:41 PM

So Apple’s offering its own Tor-like network for its customers. I wonder whether my corporate Mac will still be allowed to use this.

https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2021/06/apple-will-offer-onion-routing-for-icloud-safari-users.html

Sunday, June 27, 3:51 PM

Informative compilation from the Electronic Frontier Foundation cataloging all the different layers of surveillance infrastructure deployed against the average urban citizen by most governments.

https://www.eff.org/slsgraphic

Sunday, June 27, 4:42 PM

Today I Learned about the “Lindy effect” which postulates that the future life expectancy of non-perishable things like memes(in the original Richard Dawkins definition of the word) or practices is proportional to their current age.

Also worth perusing a newsletter about this by a dude who tries to re-interpret a lot of modern habits (especially those surrounding diet, sleep, hygiene) through the lens of the Lindy Effect.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindy_effect

Interesting primer to the tactic that is “temptation bundling”. Essentially involves pairing an unpleasant chore with a more pleasurable activity that could possibly be considered a vice.

https://www.artofmanliness.com/articles/get-better-without-torturing-yourself-the-power-of-temptation-bundling/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+theartofmanliness+%28The+Art+of+Manliness%29

Friday, June 11, 8:30 PM

Hilarious story about how an “encrypted” messaging app that was popular in “questionable” circles was actually MITM’d and operated by the FBI and other law enforcement agencies.

They patiently took their time to build their respective cases using evidence from the platform and started making arrests en-masse last week.

The point Bruce Schneier makes about the amount of “trust” required is best remembered in the context of debates around encryption apps (especially when blanket statements like “Signal is the most secure” is thrown around)

https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2021/06/fbi-afp-run-encrypted-phone.html

Friday, June 11, 8:55 PM

I never really considered baking feature flags into the CD process itself. I’ve always modelled it as a runtime configuration.

This deserves some thought.

https://dzone.com/articles/introduction-to-feature-flags-in-cd

Friday, June 11, 9:01 PM

Looks like Apple is going all-in on its approach to bind its biometric authentication implementation to the WebAuthn standard.

I’m still a bit skeptical because biometric verification approaches always end up taking away “consent” from the user to an extent as opposed a password or a pin that stays in your head.

https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/11/22529266/passkeys-icloud-keychain-ios-15-passwordless-future-security-login

Friday, June 11, 9:18 PM

I did not know that science denialism, especially the organized and backed by corporate money kind, can be traced back to big tobacco’s attempts to discredit studies that linked cigarettes to cancer.

https://doctorow.medium.com/i-quit-9ae7b6010c99

Interesting idea about segregating your music by activity you usually pair it up with. I realize I have been inadvertently doing that myself. The past few months I sort of got into the habit of getting up early to do some deep work and I usually started those sessions by putting on a Tangerine Dream record (Tangram).

The idea of segregating your music by season/time-of-the-year deserves further exploration.

https://www.artofmanliness.com/articles/how-to-create-a-soundtrack-for-your-life/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+theartofmanliness+%28The+Art+of+Manliness%29

Excellent essay on why “lean forward” or conscious consumption is extremely important in building a healthy information diet and preventing radicalization as opposed to surrendering to the algorithm and amusing ourselves to death.

https://pluralistic.net/2021/06/05/lean-back/#lean-forward

Wednesday, June 2, 9:06 AM

Interesting reference to a paper that tries to define the “capability to suffer” functionally as the ability of animals to “remember” and learn to avoid pain.

But then again because the definition is functional, it begs the same question for entities that can meet that “functional” requirement like Neural Nets.

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/Ap3BYipKmigLPAHc9/which-animals-can-suffer

Wednesday, June 2, 9:13 AM

Challenges the implication of what it means if porn is declared a public health crises.

I’ve had some run-ins with the NoFap movement myself and I think there is a lot of truth in the detrimental effects of pornography. But I guess like all addictions its usually a mask for something else (like loneliness or dissatisfaction of some kind).

If we apply the same logic should caffeine be declared a public health crisis as well ?

https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2021/06/can-you-be-addicted-porn/619040/?utm_source=feed

Wednesday, June 2, 9:18 AM

Interesting commentary on the present generation/societies obsession towards putting off commitment to anything long term and stay in a perpetual “browse” mode for extended periods of time.

Loyalty…few have it these days and that’s why I think its important.

https://www.theatlantic.com/family/archive/2021/06/pete-davis-dedicated-infinite-browsing/619039/?utm_source=feed

Wednesday, June 2, 9:39 AM

I’ve been grappling with the side effects of upper management hyper focusing on, what i consider to be, the wrong metrics for most of this year. These range from the mildly irritating (defect rate) to downright absurd (defect rate per developer).

Two adages came to mind when reading this confirmation-bias inducing essay. The famed “Cobra problem” which is a classic case of a metric gone awry and making the situation worse, and the adage that when “a measure ceases to be useful when it becomes a target”

http://rachelbythebay.com/w/2021/06/01/count/

Mildly nostalgia inducing piece about why Wordstar was the perfect word processor for creative writers.

I feel like the argument about the advantages of being a modal editor probably also carries over the the classic text editors like vi(m) or even emacs.

https://www.sfwriter.com/wordstar.htm

Tuesday, June 1, 10:54 AM

Confirmation bias read on how connections and social circle emphasize memes about certain class of people being more capable than others when in reality good fortune and being at the right place is what’s most important.

It kinda reminded me of another piece I came across a couple of days ago chronicling the fall in economic status of some Indian Royal families. Once their political power was taken away, some of these families fell through the economic rung pretty drastically over a span of 3 generations.

https://unherd.com/2021/05/what-oxford-taught-me-about-posh-people/

https://www.scoopwhoop.com/inothernews/indian-royal-families-that-are-struggling-today/

Tuesday, June 1, 10:57 AM

I had not associated continuous practice from Zen with habits from the “less wrong” community like “constant vigilance” (in matters of self improvement) and the OODA loop. I should probably brush up my Zen more

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/erZvz3tJeGLvwBz5i/zen-and-rationality-continuous-practice

Tuesday, June 1, 10:58 AM

Interesting story about someone troubleshooting their own anatomical problem after not getting any relief from professionals.

I was not aware that human anatomy is a relatively under researched topic at the moment,

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/pFqss4wW5aomDJLL9/anatomy-diseases-and-aging-damage

Tuesday, June 1, 11:02 AM

Never got into tiktok, and perhaps I’m on the wrong side of some sort of a generational barrier that precludes me from “grok”-ing tiktok.

Although I do think this whole “influencer” culture (which extends to other social networks like Instagram, Youtube etc.) is probably a large sinkhole for otherwise smart people who could make meaningful contributions to society with their intellect.

But then again, who am I to judge what is meaningful anyway.

https://harpers.org/archive/2021/06/tiktok-house-collab-house-the-anxiety-of-influencers/

QOTD

I’ve come up with a set of rules that describe our reactions to technologies:

  1. Anything that is in the world when you’re born is normal and ordinary and is just a natural part of the way the world works.

  2. Anything that’s invented between when you’re fifteen and thirty-five is new and exciting and revolutionary and you can probably get a career in it.

  3. Anything invented after you’re thirty-five is against the natural order of things.”

― Douglas Adams, The Salmon of Doubt

The only fiction I’ve read in the past year or two is science fiction (with the exception of an odd Jack Reacher novel). The idea of writing science fiction itself is intriguing and is the source of some fantasizing on my part.

Will probably check out Orson Scott Card’s “How to Write Science Fiction and Fantasy” as referenced by this essay sometime.

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/JZ9czc5CCX39wsviM/how-to-write-science-fiction-and-fantasy-a-short-summary

I guess the best argument against there being any diving arm of justice equalizing things on this earth is the fact that so many living “villains” around us end up facing no consequence at all.

It was also interesting to read about dueling efforts to preserve memory of war crimes on one side vs a perfectly understandable wish from the victims to forget about it and move on with their lives

https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2021/05/syria-bashar-assad-history/619037/?utm_source=feed

Sunday, May 30, 3:41 PM

Private internal documents that get dredged up as part of a lawsuit are always insightful in showing a companies true colors. Reminds me Microsoft’s internal machinations coming out in the Halloween papers.

Shudder and fake surprise…..Google does not really want to make privacy settings easy to find for the average joe.

https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/29/22460070/google-difficult-android-privacy-settings-arizona

One of those essay’s that come your way at the right time. I’m fairly certain I’ll need to read them again. There are no ground breaking insights in here that were completely new to me.

But its a good concise summary of the mental and credibility taxes levied by poorly thought out deadlines. I can see myself sharing these links to people over the years.

https://seths.blog/2021/05/how-to-miss-a-deadline/

https://seths.blog/2021/05/how-not-to-miss-a-deadline/

Saturday, May 29, 11:58 AM

Absolutely bonkers report about how flash cards used by US soldiers guarding sensitive spots ended up as an opsec disaster.

I vaguely remember reading reports that fitness bands and running apps(like Runkeeper and Strava) ended up inadvertently revealing unmarked military bases because people noticed public running data that indicated people running in circles in the middle of the desert where official maps say there is nothing.

If the military has this much trouble maintaining opsec hygeine imagine the predicament of a private citizen in this digital age.

https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2021/05/28/us-soldiers-expose-nuclear-weapons-secrets-via-flashcard-apps/

Saturday, May 29, 1:28 PM

I think this essay by Bruce Schneier needs to be widely read by everyone, especially my peeps who are building new and complex distributed systems on one of the major cloud providers.

The overwhelming “security strategy” seems to be to put almost all the eggs in the cloud provider’s basket and half hoping that the cloud providers really have their shit together. But as the essay argues market consolidation may have erased a lot of the security incentive from the cloud provider’s perspective.

Personal experience also tells me that most well known public cloud providers prioritize new features (while trading off runtime simplicity and by extension security) and ends up giving customers just enough rope to hang themselves while lulling them into a false sense of security.

https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2021/05/the-misaligned-incentives-for-cloud-security.html

Friday, May 28, 1:02 AM

Write up that chronicles India’s slow motion train-wreck with its indigenously developed Covid vaccine which uses the same inactivated virus tech as the Chinese vaccines.

Another related but interesting point I keep encountering when looking into Covid vaccines is that, logically the inactivated vaccines are the ones one would expect to hold up well against variants, as opposed to mRNA/Adenovirus vector based vaccines that are more preoccupied with Covid-19’s spike protein than the virus itself. But real world efficacy data from clinical trials seem to indicate the opposite.

https://www.livemint.com/science/news/how-covaxin-became-a-victim-of-vaccine-triumphalism-11622022760541.html

Friday, May 28, 12:02 PM

Informative interview with Cory Doctorow where he briefly touches on the history of copyright, patents and trade marks and attempts at properly framing Bill Gates’s vaccine philanthropy against Gates’s own historical track record (extending all the way to his Open letter to hobbyists)

https://jacobinmag.com/2021/05/cory-doctorow-interview-bill-gates-intellectual-property

Thursday, May 27, 11:41 AM

Interesting interview and idea regarding mindsets (scout vs soldier). Basic premise seems to be that the soldier mindset is obsessed with changing or attacking or defending beliefs and situations (assumed to be for the better), where as the scout mindset is centered around consciously trying to build a better “map” or with seeing things as they are instead of attacking or defending. I think I will buy her book “The Scout Mindset: Why Some People See Things Clearly and Others Don’t” and give it a read, premise sounds interesting. Even though I grew up idolizing the solider, I’m at a place where I think the explorer might be the cooler one.

https://noahpinion.substack.com/p/interview-julia-galef

The Friends : Reunion episode was pretty much everything I expected it to be (in a good way). It felt like a relatively chill hour spend in the company of old college friends.

Insightful conversation on ways to combat misinformation and things to look out for when a casual observation makes it seem like the science has not fully settled on a given topic(if may never do in totality). Also touches on the importance of trusting the source of a particular factoid and ways to critically evaluate information from seeming credible sources (e.g is this scientist writing an op-ed because his peers don’t take him seriously ?)
